name: Aztec - Coatlicue
subtitle: Coatlicue- "Serpent Skirt" / "She of the Serpent Skirt"
description:
The primordial earth mother goddess, Coatlicue embodies the duality at the heart of Aztec religion.
                Her terrifying appearance - a skirt of writhing serpents, a necklace of human hearts and hands,
                clawed feet, and two serpent heads - represents both the life-giving earth that nurtures crops and
                the devouring grave that reclaims all living things. She is creation and destruction inseparable.

The primordial earth mother goddess, Coatlicue embodies the duality at the heart of Aztec religion.
                Her terrifying appearance - a skirt of writhing serpents, a necklace of human hearts and hands,

summary:

cultural_significance: A significant deity in aztec mythology, widely worshipped and culturally influential.

topic_panels.title: Origins & Mythology
topic_panels.content:
### Sacred Origins

Aztec - Coatlicue's mythology five suns, cosmic sacrifice, Teotihuacan. The deity's role in Aztec cosmology reflects fundamental aspects of how ancient peoples understood divine power and cosmic order.

### Creation Accounts

Primary sources describe Aztec - Coatlicue's emergence and divine nature through various sacred narratives. These origin stories served both religious and cultural functions, establishing divine authority and cosmic principles.

**Time Period:** c. 1300 - 1521 CE

topic_panels.title: Worship & Practice
topic_panels.content:
### Religious Practice

Worship of Aztec - Coatlicue involved human sacrifice, blood offerings, pyramid temples. These practices created sacred bonds between devotees and the divine realm.

### Sacred Sites

Throughout Central Mexico, Mesoamerica, temples and shrines dedicated to Aztec - Coatlicue served as focal points for religious activity. Priests and priestesses maintained sacred rituals that ensured divine favor and cosmic balance.

### Festivals & Ceremonies

Special festivals celebrated Aztec - Coatlicue's divine attributes and mythological deeds, bringing communities together in shared religious expression.

topic_panels.title: Symbols & Iconography
topic_panels.content:
### Sacred Symbols

Aztec - Coatlicue is represented through various sacred symbols and iconographic elements that appear in ancient art and texts.

### Divine Attributes

The iconography reveals how ancient peoples visualized divine power and cosmic forces.

### Artistic Representations

Ancient artworks depict Aztec - Coatlicue with distinctive attributes that communicate divine identity and authority to worshippers.

topic_panels.title: Modern Influence
topic_panels.content:
### Cultural Legacy

Mexican identity, Day of the Dead, art movements. The mythology of Aztec - Coatlicue continues to resonate in contemporary culture, literature, and spiritual practices.

### Academic Study

Modern scholars analyze Aztec - Coatlicue's mythology through multiple lenses‚Äîreligious studies, anthropology, archaeology, and comparative mythology‚Äîrevealing insights into ancient worldviews.

### Popular Culture

Aztec - Coatlicue appears in modern media, from fantasy novels to video games, demonstrating the enduring power of ancient mythology to capture human imagination and address timeless questions.
